abstracts.cdata!:
The Brazil National Biodiversity
            (PROBIO) Project has a satisfactory outcome, is highly
            likely to be sustainable, and has a high institutional
            development impact. The performances of the Borrower and the
            Bank are rated satisfactory. PROBIO is already serving as a
            model for numerous other biodiversity projects in Brazil.
            Among the key lessons which have been learned through the
            successful implementation of the PROBIO project they are:
            1)Strategic, and include building consensus around problems,
            priorities, and strategies for action; incorporating
            biodiversity into other productive sectors needs to be
            promoted to achieve the greatest impact; partnering for
            biodiversity conservation established between diverse actors
            can multiply potential impact and increase sustainability;
            mobilizing the academic community to make key contributions
            by thinking outside the conventional, disciplines,
            addressing challenges, and helping resolve them in
            practical, multi-sectoral ways. 2) Informational, and
            include carefully targeting information towards key
            stakeholders; packaging information for all target audiences
            - scientists, policy makers, local communities, etc. - in a
            way that is relevant, accessible, and appealing to each;
            disseminating targeted, applied research to stimulate policy
            debate and generation; and bringing people involved in an
            initiative together for information exchange, as happened
            with subproject coordinators and in the biome workshops, to
            generate a high degree of knowledge sharing, network
            creation, and activity stimulations; 3) Operational,
            including involving all relevant relevant stakeholders from
            an early stage; being creative in developing ways to
            leverage funds (through joint calls for proposals, etc.);
            removing 1 to 1 cofinancing requirements for each
            transaction to increase flexibility under difficult fiscal
            constraints; including a high level of attention to
            methodologies and procedures; matching the calendar year of
            the project to the fiscal year of the country; and never
            assuming promises which depend on third parties; and
            4)Concern subprojects, including systematic management of
            subprojects, providing implementing teams with a kit
            containing manuals, procedures, and key documents; knowledge
            exchange among subproject coordinators, and reducing bureaucracy.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - National Biodiversity and
            Brazilian Biodiversity Fund Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the National
            Biodiversity Project is to assist the government to initiate
            a program for the conservation and sustainable use of
            biodiversty by identifying priority actions; simulating the
            development of sub-projects through the facilitation of
            partnerships between the public and private sectors; and
            disseminating biodiversity information. The project will
            include the following components: 1) biodiversity
            assessments and dissemination, which will include a
            biodiversity information network; 2) model biodiversity
            sub-projects; and 3) project administration. The main
            objective of the Brazilian Biodiversity Fund (FUNBIO)
            Project is to provide long-term and sustainable use of
            biological diversity in Brazil. The project will have two
            major components: 1) strengthening and operational support
            of FUNBIO, which will include operational costs, development
            of a cost-recovery and fund-raising program, and special
            studies to strengthen FUNBIO; and 2) grants program that
            will finance FUNBIO sub-projects. The sub-projects will be
            selected on a competitive basis according to established
            criteria. The nature of the sub-projects will include the
            following four broad areas: (a) biodiversity conservation;
            (b) sustainable use of biodiversity; (c) policy analysis;
            and (d) applied research and technology development.
